(gram.) a metrical foot consisting of one short syllable between two long ones ರಗಣ (-u-).
any accident, risk or hazard caused or likely to be caused by fire.
an ignited or fiery particle as of the one thrown off by burning wood; a spark.
kindling or feeding the sacrificial fire with clarified butter or other ritual oblations.

wood used as fuel; fire-wood.
the tree Aquilaria agallocha of Thyelaeceae family; eagle-wood; agallocham.

the Bull, a constellation coinciding with its sign in the Zodiac; the Taurus.

a sect among Kṣatriyas, the military caste.

the act of burning or marking with a hot iron; branding.

a fiery-eye, esp. the one on the forehead of Śiva, for annihilation of the world.

a piece of wood for kindling sacrificial fire.

the plant Premna spinosa.
the earth.
a mythological demon whose touch would render anything into ashes.
a brilliant meteor with a magnitude exceeding 34, esp. one that explodes; fireball; a bolide.
the ceremonial act of preparing the alter or the fireplace for a sacrifice.
one who prepares, preserves sacrificial fire and offers oblations regularly to it.

gold.
the flame of fire.
one of the seven tongues of the mythological fire or the Fire-God.
the blaze of a fire; flame.

the plant Commelina clavata (=C. salicifolia) of Commelinaceae family.
a group of six stars in the shoulder of the constellation Taurus; Pleiades.

(pl.) the three sacred fires - a) taken from the householdeṛs perpetual fire and prepared for receiving oblations, b) received from one's father, maintained and transmitted to his descendants and c) the one placed southwards.
the south-east quarter, guarded by the fire-god.

the act of causing fire to be more active; an inciting of fire.
the act of stimulating digestive power.

maintenance of sacred fire.
(vīr.) the realisation of the Supreme Light of Śiva, one of the Pañcadhāraṇes.
a genus of tailed amphibians, nearly related to the newts, harmless, but long regarded as poisonous, once supposed to live in fire; salamander.
a fiery-eye, esp. the all-destructing eye on the forehead of Śiva.
Śiva, who has an extraordinary eye on the forehead for the final destruction of the universe.
resisting fire; fire-proof; incombustible.
that which is fire-proof.
a dance performed by a group of people encircling fire.

any difficult test.
the act of kindling, causing, fire burn with flame.
the tree Anocardium occidentale.
its kidney-shaped nuts.
a mountain with a central pipe from deep below, a crater on top that erupts subterranean matter as lava, ash, etc; a volcano.

the act of refining by means of fire; purification with fire.

one of the eighteen chief classic sacred books of Hindus, supposed to have been compiled by sage Vēda Vyāsa.
the personified fire; Fire-God.
fire-worship; pyrolatry.

self immolation of a widow following her husbaṇḍs death.
devastation caused by fire.
carbon in its pure, extremely hard and crystallised (in isometric system) form; diamond.
the digestive power.

an advocate of extreme action; an extremist.
produced from fire; fire-born.

having fire for mouth or emitting fire from the mouth.
